Award.AwardTitle: SNM: Continuous and Scalable Nanomanufacturing for 3-Dimensional Functional Biomedical Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Diabetes, heart failure, and hepatic failure are diseases of enormous burden to Americans. The effective therapies for these often lethal diseases require the application of novel engineering concepts and technologies. Tissue engineering holds great promise for the treatment of these diseases. Using biodegradable scaffolds, cells are organized in close proximity to each other with a well-defined 3-dimensional (3D) space for the formation of new tissues. While a typical biological cell has a size of several microns, the interactions of cells with the environment occur at a nanoscale. Fabricating such scaffolds with micro- and nano-scale features has been a significant bottleneck for industrial scale production of tissues. The goal of this research is to develop a novel nanomanufacturing system, Hyperlens-Assisted Projection Stereolithography (HAPS), with a sub-50 nm resolution for the direct-write of 3D, heterogeneous biological scaffolds. The research tasks include: a) design and fabrication of the hyperlens by combining simulation with experiments, b) integration of the hyperlens with the projection stereolithography system, c) design and fabrication of complex tissue scaffolds, and d) studying the growth and phenotypical modulation of vascular endothelial cells and smooth muscle cells using the scaffolds.

If successful, this project will help to enhance the emerging US biomanufacturing industry for the production of vascular tissues, skins, bones, and other tissues and organs. The proposed HAPS technique will foster a giant step for scalable, continuous 3D nanomanufacturing of not only functional biomedical devices, but also 3D nanoelectronics, nanophotonics, and nanoenergy devices. Moreover, the results of this work will provide inspiring teaching materials and interesting laboratory projects. The proposed efforts of integrating research with education will offer undergraduates and graduate students increased exposure to nanomanufacturing. The proposed symposia and workshop will greatly enhance the impact of nanomanufacturing research.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research is to investigate fundamental phenomena in light-materials interactions and use such knowledge to create innovative nano-fabrication processes for the development of three dimensional functional biomedical devices. The research approach includes: 1) Conducted numerical simulations of the light focusing properties, developed nanofabrication processes to create a hyperlens, and then tested lithography performance using such a hyperlens for nanoscale light delivery, 2) demonstrated a rapid 3D printing method using projected light pattern to polymerize hydrogels, 3) designed and 3D-printed biological scaffolds with unique mechanical, physical, chemical, and biological properties in hydrogels for cell studies, 4) characterized the nanophotonic materials and hydrogel scaffolds using advanced instruments such as atomic force microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and confocal microscopy, 5) conducted experiments to investigate the cellular responses to the scaffolds of various properties using cardiac cells, smooth muscle cells, and other cell types, 6) developed novel device applications such as an artificial micro-fish and liver-mimic detoxification devices. 

This work has led to significant outcomes including: 1) theoretical understanding the quantum limit for the resolution of the hyperlens and successful demonstration of such novel hyperlens, 2) successful demonstration of the rapid 3D printing process using light projection and continuous image process. Such a rapid printing process allows one to create 3D devices with superior structural integrity as compared to traditional nozzle or ink-jet based 3D printing approaches, 3) comprehensive understanding of cell interactions with micro-environments using precision scaffolds by 3D printing, 4) successful demonstration of novel functional devices: the micro-fish could be useful as a nano-robot and the artificial liver could be used for detoxification.

During the course of the project, 3 postdoc fellows and 5 graduate students from three departments (NanoEngineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, and Bioengineering) have worked in the multi-disciplinary team with significant training in optics, nanomanufacturing, and biomedical nanotechnology. 10 undergraduate researchers have been involved in this project. The undergraduate students learned how to team up with the graduate students on the experiments, and learned how to conduct scientific experiments, specifically learned how to use different lasers optics, instruments (SEM and optical microscope), and cell culture. 20 peer-reviewed journal papers, several conference papers, and book chapters have been published with support from this grant. Many papers are joint publications as a result of this collaborative project.

Results from this project has been presented in a variety of society meetings, especially the key conferences of the optics, biomedical and manufacturing societies, including ASME International Conference on Manufacturing Science & Engineering, Biomedical Engineering Society Annual conference, World Biomaterials Congress, IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Conference, National Academy of Engineering Frontiers of Engineering Symposium, NSF Additive Manufacturing for Health Workshop, and Materials Research Society (MRS) Spring Meeting. Results from this project have also been used as a part of course materials of graduate and undergraduate courses, including Nano 239 – “Nanomanufacturing” (average enrollment 40 students per year), NANO 112 “Synthesis and Fabrication of Nanoengineering Systems” (average enrollment 70 students per year), Nano101 – “Introduction to Nanoengineering” (average enrollment 100 students per year), and Nano 150 –“Mechanics of Nanomaterials” (average enrollment 20 students per year). 

 


Last Modified: 09/03/2016
Modified by: Shaochen Chen

    Shaochen Chen, University of California, San Diego

    3D-printed Micro-fish
